tier.item: This observation is also made in Przepi rkowski & Kup (1997a).
Adam Przepi rkowski (p.c.) notes that the case of bez presents a problem for my claim that
n-words and non-n-words are in complementary distribution. However, I make this claim on
the basis of the distribution of n-words and non-n-words in contexts of local negation, higher
clause negation and non-negative contexts (recall table 1) and no claim is made concerning
their distribution in other environments. Examples like (32) present an interesting case as it
seems that -kolwiek-type NPIs have here a special meaning, comparable to that of strong
NPIs discussed by Kadmon & Landman (1993) and Krifka (1995). In short, the
J. B aszczak, Towards a Binding Analysis of Negative Polarity Items in Polish

tier.item: adne. I think that the reason for that is the fact that the questions in (44) and (45) are
strongly presuppositional, i.e. it is presupposed that the `addressee' has read some book or
has seen some child. Thus, a full answer, explicitly denying such a presupposition, is more
appropriate in this case, cf. (44') Nie przeczyta em adnej ksi ki (`I didn't read any
book') and (45') Nie widzia em adnego dziecka (`I didn't see any child').
Notice that almost may modify e.g. nothing in there-sentences, cf.
(i) There is almost nothing in the fridge.
Keenan (1987:292) defines almost no as `basic existential determiner'.
Adam Przepi rkowski (p.c.) remarks that it does not make much sense to say that prawie is
bad with czegokolwiek here because the sentence is bad anyway, cf. *Nie zjad
czegokolwiek (`He didn't eat anything'). This is of course true, but the facts are more
complicated. Given what we have said so far about the licensing of non-n-words, one could
expect that since they are licensed by higer clause negation it should be possible to modify
J. B aszczak, Towards a Binding Analysis of Negative Polarity Items in Polish

tier.item: As is well-known, preposition stranding is not possible in Polish. Therefore, there are no Polish analogues to (24) to
demonstrate that it is the definition of lexical government which is at issue. As noted in Rappaport 1995 , the failure
of extraction from PrepP is not just a matter of ensuring that the trace of the complement of P satisfies the ECP, as a
PrepP serves as a barrier to any extraction from inside it.

This example stems from Adam Przepiórkowski's "Toy Corpus", an early predecessor of the
IPI PAN corpus, which has been disconnected recently.

Also Saloni and [widzi ski 1985 assume after Saloni 1976 that verbal negation is a morphological
category, but they change their stance in Saloni and [widzi ski 1998, citing long distance Genitive of Negation
facts discussed in Przepi rkowski and [widzi ski 1997. Also Menantaud 1989 and Wr bel 1998 explicitly
reject the position of Saloni 1976 and Saloni and [widzi ski 1985, essentially on the same grounds. See,
however, 5.2.3 for an analysis of long distance GoN compatible with the pre xal nature of verbal nie, and
also Witko 1998 for a Minimalist analysis of long distance GoN assuming the pre xal status of nie.
Verbal negation should be carefully distinguished from the constituent negation homonymous in Polish,
which does not comply with any of the observations cited here.

tier.item: See Bailyn 1995 for an analysis of secondary predication in Russian which is consistent with this con-
clusion. The main predictive di erence between that analysis, which is claimed to be valid also for Polish
Bailyn, 1995, p.340, and the analysis developed below is that Bailyn 1995 predicts that in the case of a
predicative instrumental attaching to a transitive verb, it will predicate of the accusative ob ject, and not of
the nominative sub ject. Although this seems to be a valid tendency, it does not seem to be absolute, cf. Bailyn
1995, p.339, examples 34 and, especially, i in fn.14. However, should this tendency be modelled in the
syntax, our analysis below can be easily modi ed to the e ect that an instrumental predicate may predicate
of not just any structural NP on an arg-st, but of the last such NP.
This is the only suchverb listed in [widzi ski 1994.

tier.item: 10.40 a. Bielany le mil *mili od Warszawy.
Bielany lie mile mile from Warsaw
As brie y discussed in 10.1.1 above, this has also been noted for Russian, e.g., by Babby 1980a cf. also
Timberlake 1975, Babby 1980b, fn.2, Babby 1986, fn.43, Fowler 1987, pp.307f., who claims that in
the only reason that sub jects, direct ob jects, and time adverbs are marked genitive under negation
is that they do not happen to be marked by an oblique case p.86, see also p.150.
Actually, Willim 1990, p.211 and Ta jsner 1990, p.246 deny that adjuncts can undergo GoN. On the
other hand, Holvoet 1991, p.85 and Franks and Dziwirek 1993 consider such examples grammatical. We
are not sure if this is the result of a genuine variation, or whether Willim's and Ta jsner's judgements stem from
the fact that additional presuppositions are connected with the genitive variant, pace Holvoet 1991, p.85,
or that they may have partitive meaning, pace Franks and Dziwirek 1993. In any case, all our informants
